item.description:
We begin our study of the American Pragmatists with the original pragmatist, Charles Sanders Peirce. This will be the first of two or three sessions on Peirce. Peirce’s philosophical work breaks down into phases, each with a complete philosophical system.

The first system of his youth was an attempt to develop a Semiotic idealism that combined Kant’s Transcendental Analytic with Platonic idealism. The second system includes his Subject-Predicate theory of propositions as well as his “New List” of categories. The third system develops his Doubt-Belief theory and influential Pragmatist theory of meaning. In the fourth system he completes another revision of categories as the basis for his Theory of cognition and reality.

At our first meeting on Peirce we will take a look at his writings from the period of his second system. Further meetings will explore the development of his third and fourth systems. Below is a list of all readings and links to where they can be found online. For those interested in reading in the traditional book format I would recommend The Essential Peirce-Selected Philosophical Writings Vol. 1 & 2 edited by the Peirce Edition Project and published by Indiana University Press.
